trans-unit.source: Group by options in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Group by options in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for implementing group by options in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for implementing group by options in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: The [GROUP BY] clause is used to aggregate data to a summary set of rows.
trans-unit.target: The [GROUP BY] clause is used to aggregate data to a summary set of rows.

trans-unit.source: It also has a few options that extend it's functionality that need to be worked around as they are not directly supported by Azure SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: It also has a few options that extend it's functionality that need to be worked around as they are not directly supported by Azure SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: These options are
trans-unit.target: These options are

trans-unit.source: GROUP BY with ROLLUP
trans-unit.target: GROUP BY with ROLLUP

trans-unit.source: GROUPING SETS
trans-unit.target: GROUPING SETS

trans-unit.source: GROUP BY with CUBE
trans-unit.target: GROUP BY with CUBE

trans-unit.source: The simplest option here is to use UNION ALL instead to perform the rollup rather than relying on the explicit syntax.
trans-unit.target: The simplest option here is to use UNION ALL instead to perform the rollup rather than relying on the explicit syntax.

trans-unit.source: The result is exactly the same
trans-unit.target: The result is exactly the same

trans-unit.source: Below is an example of a group by statement using the ROLLUP option:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example of a group by statement using the ROLLUP option:

trans-unit.source: By using ROLLUP we have requested the following aggregations:
trans-unit.target: By using ROLLUP we have requested the following aggregations:

trans-unit.source: Country and Region
trans-unit.target: Country and Region

trans-unit.source: Country
trans-unit.target: Country

trans-unit.source: Grand Total
trans-unit.target: Grand Total

trans-unit.source: To replace this you will need to use UNION ALL; specifying the aggregations required explicitly to return the same results:
trans-unit.target: To replace this you will need to use UNION ALL; specifying the aggregations required explicitly to return the same results:

trans-unit.source: For GROUPING SETS all we need to do is adopt the same principal but only create UNION ALL sections for the aggregation levels we want to see
trans-unit.target: For GROUPING SETS all we need to do is adopt the same principal but only create UNION ALL sections for the aggregation levels we want to see

trans-unit.source: It is possible to create a GROUP BY WITH CUBE using the UNION ALL approach.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to create a GROUP BY WITH CUBE using the UNION ALL approach.

trans-unit.source: The problem is that the code can quickly become cumbersome and unwieldy.
trans-unit.target: The problem is that the code can quickly become cumbersome and unwieldy.

trans-unit.source: To mitigate this you can use this more advanced approach.
trans-unit.target: To mitigate this you can use this more advanced approach.

trans-unit.source: Let's use the example above.
trans-unit.target: Let's use the example above.

trans-unit.source: The first step is to define the 'cube' that defines all the levels of aggregation that we want to create.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to define the 'cube' that defines all the levels of aggregation that we want to create.

trans-unit.source: It is important to take note of the CROSS JOIN of the two derived tables.
trans-unit.target: It is important to take note of the CROSS JOIN of the two derived tables.

trans-unit.source: This generates all the levels for us.
trans-unit.target: This generates all the levels for us.

trans-unit.source: The rest of the code is really there for formatting.
trans-unit.target: The rest of the code is really there for formatting.

trans-unit.source: The results of the CTAS can be seen below:
trans-unit.target: The results of the CTAS can be seen below:

trans-unit.source: The second step is to specify a target table to store interim results:
trans-unit.target: The second step is to specify a target table to store interim results:

trans-unit.source: The third step is to loop over our cube of columns performing the aggregation.
trans-unit.target: The third step is to loop over our cube of columns performing the aggregation.

trans-unit.source: The query will run once for every row in the #Cube temporary table and store the results in the #Results temp table
trans-unit.target: The query will run once for every row in the #Cube temporary table and store the results in the #Results temp table

trans-unit.source: Lastly we can return the results by simply reading from the #Results temporary table
trans-unit.target: Lastly we can return the results by simply reading from the #Results temporary table

trans-unit.source: By breaking the code up into sections and generating a looping construct the code becomes more manageable and maintainable.
trans-unit.target: By breaking the code up into sections and generating a looping construct the code becomes more manageable and maintainable.
